course_title: Applied Research in Criminology and Criminal Justice 1

learning_outcomes.description: Undertake necessary preparation for applied research projects, including liaising with research and industry partners and/or clients
Construct a critical review of a published body of research in your discipline area
Construct a research proposal using a recognised research design methodology within the Criminology discipline
Engage actively and effectively in teamwork
Report on research work in progress to various audiences
Relate your learning to the practice of criminology and how your work is distinguished from existing knowledge, as well as articulating the significance of the research.
Apply an understanding of the ethical implications of research, including sustainable generative AI.

assessments.task_description:
For this task, you will be asked to collaborate with your group members via Microsoft Teams, a widely used collaborative tool in Industry. In our workshop each week, you will work together on various aspects of project planning to progress and develop your ideas collaboratively. Roles in class will be rotated week by week, so each student will have a chance to act as group leader, facilitator/mediator, spokesperson, notetaker, questioner throughout the semester.

Each week, by the end of the workshop, results of specific tasks (explained in class) will need to be recorded on your group’s Teams page by your group. There is no set word limit for the tasks, but you should ensure that you respond to all the tasks with sufficient detail.

Your individual contribution to the weekly planning will be assessed by the course coordinator both during your in-class discussions, through the contributions you make on Teams during the session, and through a declaration from each group member about the contributions of each individual to the task.

Students are expected to attend class every week to ensure their project and group work progresses throughout the semester. However, grades for this assessment will be based on the best 7 attempts. If you are unable to attend a workshop due to illness or other extenuating circumstances, please contact the course coordinator (prior to class) to determine how best to contribute to your team’s project planning for that week.

Artificial Intelligence (AI) provides emerging tools that may support students in completing this assessment task. Students may appropriately use AI in completing this assessment task. Students must clearly reference any use of AI in each instance and be clear why they have chosen to use AI. A failure to reference AI use may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct. Additional resources are available through UQ AI Student Hub.
assessments.submission_guidelines: Tasks will be assessed within the Microsoft Teams group page for each project group.

assessments.task_description:
In this individual piece of assessment, you are required to identify 5 pieces of literature for the development and planning of your research proposal. You must provide a brief statement summarising your research problem, provide a summary of the key findings/argument of each piece; and explain how each piece is relevant to your proposed research. This can include articles relevant to your methodology, such as a study using similar methodology, not necessarily on the same substantive topic. There is no set word limit on each item, but the overall length of your Annotated Bibliography assignment should not exceed 1400 words, excluding the bibliographic details of key references and your full reference list for the assignment.

You can work as a team in formulating your research problem or devise your own. If you all use the same research problem, you will all receive the same mark for that component of the assessment. Writing separate ones may actually benefit you as a team since you'll end up with multiple iterations of your research problem, allowing you to make comparisons on how you each perceive the project and to select the most suitable for inclusion in your research proposal further down the track.

Research teams must work together to plan the focus of work for each team member so that, taken together, the references submitted by each student and the feedback they receive will form the basis of the team's review of literature for your Research Proposal. As a group, you are encouraged to run your list of references past your academic advisor to ensure you have covered the main texts and bodies of literature, but do not send them your individual annotated bibliographies for review.

This task has been designed to be challenging, authentic and complex. Whilst students may use AI and/or MT technologies, successful completion of assessment in this course will require students to critically engage in specific contexts and tasks for which artificial intelligence will provide only limited support and guidance. Students must complete an AI usage declaration and submit it with their assignment. A failure to reference generative AI or MT use may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct. Additional resources are available through UQ AI Student Hub.
assessments.submission_guidelines: You must submit your assessment electronically by the due time, on the due date.

assessments.task_description:
A core component of social research involves considering the ethical implications of our actions (or inactions). Before embarking on your research, ethical clearance from an UQ Ethics Committee is likely to be needed. This process requires weighing the risks and benefits of the research and any distress or discomfort that may be caused by what you are doing, and provide the Ethics Committee a clear description of your project and how your will manage these risks and consent of research participants.

Each project will have different ethical considerations. In order to give you some practice in this process for your project and projects you may complete in the future, you will need to consider two of the three scenarios and describe (in ~500 words each) any (a) potential risks/harms relating to human participants, (b) how you might manage those risks, and (c) your responsibilities in managing the data.

Resources will be provided in class, but the National Statement on Ethical Conduct in Human Research will be fundamental to your task: (https://www.nhmrc.gov.au/about-us/publications/national-statement-ethical-conduct-human-research-2025 ) 

This task has been designed to be challenging, authentic and complex. Whilst students may use AI technologies, successful completion of an assessment task about ETHICAL decisions and considerations will require students to critically engage with the specific contexts presented in an ETHICAL manner, for which artificial intelligence will provide only limited support and guidance. If AI is utilised in this assessment task, it must be referenced and clearly explained why its use was necessary. Students must complete an AI usage declaration and submit it with their assignment. Failure to do so will result in a grade of zero for the assignment.

A failure to reference AI use may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.

assessments.task_description:
Being able to summarise and present your work concisely or to a varied audience is an important skill. For this piece of assessment groups will need to represent their proposed project design in a visually engaging poster accompanied by a brief presentation (~5-10mins), Q&A session, and full written proposal.

Poster Presentation

Students’ explanations must cover the elements represented in the poster (research problem/gap/issue, research questions/aims, proposed methods and framework). Students will deliver their presentations during class in Week 13, and will be asked to respond to questions from the audience (including the course coordinator), and their poster and will be submitted via Blackboard Ultra on that day, along with their full proposal (detailed below).

Posters should be a single PowerPoint slide designed in a landscape orientation and should ensure all fonts are of a readable size.

Proposal

In this piece of assessment, you are required to submit a proposal outlining your research problem and your plan for undertaking the research. Some of this work will have been done already in your research plan for your ethics application, so you can build on the work you have already done. In your proposal, you should outline the following:

·        a clear problem statement that the project seeks to address;

·        rationale (reason) for your research, including its contribution to the broad field of practice and scholarly literature in which the work sits, plus any anticipated outcomes;

·        the specific aims of your proposed research and a statement of your research questions;

·        any concepts or theories that you draw on;

·        the methods you propose to use;

·        how you will sample and recruit participants and/or obtain documents or other data for your research, and gather other information;

·        how you will record and manage data;

·        how you will conduct your analysis;

·        a timeline and budget of required resources.

·        any ethical concerns arising from your project and how you propose to address them.

You will be provided with critical feedback based on the key criteria for assessment of your Group Research Project Proposal. It is expected that you will incorporate this feedback into your research design before embarking upon your research in CRIM3202 in Semester 2. The course coordinator can provide you with guidance on this.

Each student must also submit a Peer Assessment for this assignment via BuddyCheck (via Blackboard Ultra) on the due date. No marks are specifically allocated to the Peer Assessment, but failure to complete the Peer Assessment will result in zero marks. In circumstances where the Peer Assessment indicates significant disparities in group contributions, the Course Coordinator can also adjust individual team members’ marks on the assignment accordingly.

This task has been designed to be challenging, authentic and complex. Whilst students may use AI and/or MT technologies, successful completion of assessment in this course will require students to critically engage in specific contexts and tasks for which artificial intelligence will provide only limited support and guidance. A failure to reference generative AI or MT use may also constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct. Even if AI is not used, an AI statement completed by each group member must be submitted with the assignment, otherwise that student will receive zero marks. To pass this assessment, students will be required to demonstrate detailed comprehension of their written submission independent of AI and MT tools via conversations with the course coordinator during workshops throughout the semester. Group members will also assess their peers’ understanding through the submission of Buddycheck.

Students must individually complete an AI usage declaration and submit it with their assignment. Students must also complete a Buddycheck, assessing the contributions of others in their project team. Failure to include the AI declaration or complete the Buddycheck will result in a grade of zero for the assignment.
assessments.submission_guidelines: One person must submit your assignment electronically on behalf of the team by the due time, on the due date. All students must also submit their own individual Peer Assessment via BuddyCheck and a Generative AI use statement.
